items.title: In-cluster config support? object has no attribute 'configuration'
items.body:
Hi there,

I created a simple script, if I use it from my workstation everything works properly, because the configuration is loaded from my client config (KUBECONFIG).
I use the following snippet as readme:

```
k8s_client = config.new_client_from_config()
dyn_client = DynamicClient(k8s_client)
```

But when I tried to run this script in the ocp cluster using the "in cluster config" from kubernetes api client(example here: https://github.com/kubernetes-client/python/blob/master/examples/in_cluster_config.py#L55) like this:

```
k8s_client = config.load_incluster_config()
dyn_client = DynamicClient(k8s_client)
```
I receive an error:
```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/src/app/app.py", line 24, in <module>
    dyn_client = DynamicClient(k8s_client)
  File "/usr/local/lib/python3.8/site-packages/openshift/dynamic/client.py", line 70, in __init__
    self.configuration = client.configuration
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'configuration'
```
Is in-cluster config supported? basically to run something from inside a pod

items.title: openshift installs a version of pyyaml with an open CVE
items.body:
The currently released version of `openshift` depends on `kubernetes==10.1.0` which in turn is pinning an old version of `pyyaml` with a high-severity open CVE:

https://github.com/kubernetes-client/python/blob/v10.1.0/requirements.txt#L5
https://github.com/advisories/GHSA-rprw-h62v-c2w7

```shell
$ pip install openshift && pip freeze | grep -i yaml
PyYAML==3.13
```

_This_ recent change, which unpins the version of `kubernetes`, would probably fix this issue.  Is there any ETA on when this will land in a new published version of `openshift`?

https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/commit/4498aaccf13cf18858768a9f069c60929bbaa679

related: https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/issues/289

items.title: AttributeError in Discoverer.__init__ method when using Windows
items.body:
After updating from version 0.8.1 to 0.10.0 I can't use `dyn_client = DynamicClient(k8s_client)` (like shown in the examples) anymore. When calling it, I get the following error:
``AttributeError: module 'os' has no attribute 'getuid'``
Apparently, the init method of the Discoverer class uses `os.getuid` to define default_cachefile_name. Unfortunately, this is only supported for Unix not for Windows.
Is there a way to avoid this error when using Windows?

items.title: Client init fails if one of apis is unavailable
items.body:
Hi!
I've faced issue with client init. There are number of custom apis(ApiService resources) in my cluster, like, for example, /apis/metrics.k8s.io/v1beta1. It appeared that not all of apis might work all the time, some apis might stop answering. I'm not sure if that is ok situation, but if such minor api fails, I'd like my cluster's core functionality(running containers, making changes to deployments, etc) continued working.
This discovery code https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/master/openshift/dynamic/discovery.py#L108 is pretty good now, but it fails openshift python client in case of one failed minor api(logic "full api discovery failed == client init failed").
Unfortunately I'm not proposing PR to fix that, but I suggest to change that behavior to "some apis discovery failed == continue working and fail if user requested api that is not discovered").

items.title: How do I best determine if a manifest already exists?
items.body:
I'd like to determine if a ConfigMap already exists before I create it so I can take appropriate actions. How do I accomplish this? 

Here is the code I've tried:
```
#!/usr/bin/env python3

import os
import sys
import yaml
from kubernetes import client, config
from openshift.dynamic import DynamicClient
import openshift.dynamic.exceptions

# Check if code is running in OpenShift
if "OPENSHIFT_BUILD_NAME" in os.environ:
    config.load_incluster_config()
    file_namespace = open(
        "/run/secrets/kubernetes.io/serviceaccount/namespace", "r"
    )
    if file_namespace.mode == "r":
        namespace = file_namespace.read()
        print("namespace: %s\n" %(namespace))
else:
    config.load_kube_config()

# Configure cluster access 
k8s_config = client.Configuration()
k8s_client = client.api_client.ApiClient(configuration=k8s_config)
dyn_client = DynamicClient(k8s_client)

v1_configmaps = dyn_client.resources.get(api_version='v1', kind='ConfigMap')

cm_name = "rh-operators-not-here"
cm_namespace = "operator-lifecycle-manager"
try:
    configmap_list = v1_configmaps.get(namespace=cm_namespace,name=cm_name)
except 'NotFoundError':
    print("WARNING: ConfigMap " + cm_name + " not found in namespace " + cm_namespace + ". We will create it.")
    pass
except 'kubernetes.client.rest.ApiException':
    print("apiexception")
    pass
except NameError:
    print("nameerror")
    pass
except:
    print("Unexpected error:", sys.exc_info()[0])
    raise
```

When I run that, twice I get "During handling of the above exception, another exception occurred" and then all the output ends in "TypeError: catching classes that do not inherit from BaseException is not allowed".

How do I properly catch this so I can determine if I should .create or .replace it?

items.title: 0.9.x no longer patches existing object correctly
items.body:
I have an object called VirtualMachineInstanceReplicaSet/myvmir. I want to increase its `spec.replicas` from 1 to 2. Here's how I'd do it:

```
[mmazur@klapek work1]$ cat ansible_scale.yml
---
- name: Comprehensive kubevirt_vm testing
  hosts: localhost
  connection: local
  tasks:
  - name: scale
    k8s:
      inline:
        apiVersion: kubevirt.io/v1alpha3
        kind: VirtualMachineInstanceReplicaSet
        metadata:
          name: myvmir
          namespace: default
        spec:
          replicas: 2
```

Running ansible-playbook on this with `openshift-0.8.9 kubernetes-8.0.2 urllib3-1.24.3`, everything works as expected and I get _"changed": true, (…), "method": "patch"_ in the result.

But then I upgrade to _kubernetes-9.0.1 openshift-0.9.2_ and running the same gets me an _apply_ instead of a _patch_ and an assorted webhook validation error:

```
(…)
    "msg": "Failed to apply object: b'{\"kind\":\"Status\",\"apiVersion\":\"v1\",\"metadata\":{},\"status\":\"Failure\",\"message\":\"admission webhook \\\\\"virtualmachinereplicaset-validator.kubevirt.io\\\\\" denied the request: spec.selector in body is required, spec.template in body is required\",\"reason\":\"Invalid\",\"details\":{\"causes\":[{\"message\":\"spec.selector in body is required\"},{\"message\":\"spec.template in body is required\"}]},\"code\":422}\\n'",
    "reason": "Unprocessable Entity",
    "status": 422
```

Granted, this might be an overreaction on the admission webhook's part and this should work the same both for _apply_ and _patch_, not sure. In any event, any chance I can force 0.9.x to try to _patch_ instead of _apply_?

items.title: uncap kubernetes version
items.body:
At the moment openshift-restclient-python is the only package requiring a specific version of the kubernetes python library.  This causes co-installability issues. This blocks others from using new versions of kubernetes until you update/release.  At that point they'd have to switch to the new version as you only support one version at a time.

http://logs.openstack.org/04/657204/3/check/requirements-tox-py27-check-uc/0d243cf/job-output.txt.gz#_2019-05-07_14_43_24_123381

specifically the following line

    ContextualVersionConflict: (kubernetes 9.0.0 (/home/zuul/src/opendev.org/openstack/requirements/.tox/py27-check-uc/lib/python2.7/site-packages), Requirement.parse('kubernetes<9.0.0,>=8.0.0'), set(['openshift']))

Would it be possible to uncap the version of kubernetes you support.  If you want to limit the version in your installs that is what constraints are for, see the following for an example.

https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/16e8fd6a0f179e3cad0ae2197a5c1be18ada2ea1/upper-constraints.txt#L427
https://github.com/openstack/requirements/blob/16e8fd6a0f179e3cad0ae2197a5c1be18ada2ea1/tox.ini#L19

if 1.3.0 comes out for foo (see below) the following would happen.

    #in requirements.txt
    foo>=1.0.0
    #in constraints.txt
    foo===1.2.3
    
    pip install foo -r requirements.txt -c constraints.txt
    # would install 1.2.3 even though 1.3.0 is done

items.title: matches.extend(self.__search([key] + parts[1:], resources)) TypeError: 'Resource' object is not iterable
items.body:
[This line](https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/v0.8.7/openshift/dynamic/client.py#L679) allows for a recursive call to return a _non-iterable_ value which causes `extend` to throw this error. 

_I noticed that the latest code completely changes, but given that it is still tagged as alpha, and a minor version bump, i thought you might want to know...  We pegged our pip install to 0.8.6, so feel free to close and focus on 0.9_

items.title: Downstream/ansible preparations for 0.9
items.body:
There's a few possible incompatibilities between code that works with 0.8 and code that would work with 0.9 as well. The easiest to spot is that `from openshift import watch` is no longer something that works with 0.9.

However that code is present in ansible 2.8 (to be released in 6 weeks) in two places: `k8s`'s module_utils and `kubevirt`'s as well. And that's just that one particular incompatibility.

I'd like to discuss the way 0.9 is going to get released (and maybe when?). Once ansible 2.8 is out if 0.9 gets pushed to pip, then people's modules will just stop working on any fresh ansible installation (as `pip install openshift` will fetch 0.9 by default).

What I guess might happen is something like this:

1. 0.9 is scheduled to be released.
2. Compatibility fixes are pushed into latest ansible (be it 2.8.x or 2.9).`
3. Said ansible gets released.
4. Only then is 0.9 pushed out.

But that's just off the top of my head. Something else is in the works maybe?

items.title: can not update k8s configmap
items.body:
1. create or update configmap task file
```yaml
- name: create or update app configmap
  k8s:
    state: present
    src: /opt/k8s/app.yaml
  register: execute_result
```

2. app configmap yaml
```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: "app-config"
  namespace: "default"
data:
  SERVICE_NAME: "app"
  server_port: "20080"
```
3. Run the ansible task and exec command `kubectl get cm app-config -o yaml`
```
apiVersion: v1
data:
  SERVICE_NAME: app
  server_port: "20080"
kind: ConfigMap
...
```
4. edit app configmap yaml and add `tmp: "blabla"`
```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: "app-config"
  namespace: "default"
data:
  SERVICE_NAME: "app"
  server_port: "20080"
  tmp: "blabla"
```
5. Run the ansible task and exec command `kubectl get cm app-config -o yaml`
```
apiVersion: v1
data:
  SERVICE_NAME: app
  server_port: "20080"
  tmp: "blabla"
kind: ConfigMap
...
```
6. edit app configmap yaml and remove `tmp: "blabla"`
```yaml
apiVersion: v1
kind: ConfigMap
metadata:
  name: "app-config"
  namespace: "default"
data:
  SERVICE_NAME: "app"
  server_port: "20080"
```
7. Run the ansible task and exec command `kubectl get cm app-config -o yaml`, **_the configuration data `tmp: "blabla"` still exists!_**
```
apiVersion: v1
data:
  SERVICE_NAME: app
  server_port: "20080"
  tmp: "blabla"
kind: ConfigMap
...
```

items.title: Unsupported Media Type when try to update a ServiceMonitor
items.body:
When I try to create a custom resource, in my case a `ServiceMonitor` from `monitoring.coreos.com/v1` I got the error: `Failed to patch object: b'{\"kind\":\"Status\",\"apiVersion\":\"v1\",\"metadata\":{},\"status\":\"Failure\",\"message\":\"the body of the request was in an unknown format - accepted media types include: application/json-patch+json, application/merge-patch+json\",\"reason\":\"UnsupportedMediaType\",\"code\":415}\\n'`

A ansible code example, but you need to run twice:
```yaml
-  k8s:
    state: present
    context: "your k8s context name"
    namespace: "monitoring"
    resource_definition:
```

items.title: Watch is not working with dynamic client
items.body:
I have 0.7.1 client and I'm trying to make watch request.
This works:
```python
from openshift import watch
from openshift import client
from openshift.client import BuildOpenshiftIoV1Api

openshift_client = client.ApiClient()
build_api_client = BuildOpenshiftIoV1Api(openshift_client)
watcher = watch.Watch()
for event in watcher.stream(
    build_api_client.list_namespaced_build,
    namespace='my-test-namespace',
    field_selector='metadata.name={}'.format('my-test-buildname-3'),
    resource_version=0,
    timeout_seconds=600
):
    print(type(event))
```
and this is not:
```python
from openshift import watch
from openshift import dynamic
from openshift.dynamic import Resource

dyn_client = dynamic.DynamicClient()
dyn_build_api: Resource = dyn_client.resources.get(
    api_version='build.openshift.io/v1', kind='Build'
)
watcher = watch.Watch()
for event in watcher.stream(
    dyn_build_api.get,
    namespace='my-test-namespace',
    field_selector='metadata.name={}'.format('my-test-buildname-3'),
    resource_version=0,
    timeout_seconds=600
):
    print(type(event))
```
it never hits "print" because it makes it's first request on
/apis/build.openshift.io/v1/namespaces/my-test-namespace/builds?fieldSelector=metadata.name%3Dmy-test-buildname-3&resourceVersion=0&timeoutSeconds=600&watch=True and hangs waiting for it. I haven't been digging deeper, but I put print into kubernetes/client/api_client.py:317
```
print(resource_path, method,
                                   path_params, query_params, header_params,
                                   body, post_params, files,
                                   response_type, auth_settings,
                                   _return_http_data_only, collection_formats, _preload_content, _request_timeout)
```
and this is how working watch request looks like:
```
/apis/build.openshift.io/v1/namespaces/{namespace}/builds
GET {'namespace': 'my-test-namespace'}
[('fieldSelector', 'metadata.name=my-test-buildname-2'), ('resourceVersion', '0'), ('timeoutSeconds', 600), ('watch', True)]
{'Accept': 'application/json', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
None [] {} V1BuildList ['BearerToken', 'Oauth2AccessToken', 'Oauth2Implicit'] True {} False None
```
and this is how infinite waiting request looks like:
```
/apis/build.openshift.io/v1/namespaces/my-test-namespace/builds
GET {}
[('fieldSelector', 'metadata.name=my-test-buildname-3'), ('resourceVersion', '0'), ('timeoutSeconds', 600), ('watch', True)]
{'Accept': 'application/json', 'Content-Type': 'application/json'}
None [] {} None ['BearerToken'] True None False None
```
Looks loke dynamic client in some cases shouldn't render path with namespace built into it, but just proxy it as is to kubernetes api_client.

items.title: b64encode expects bytes not string
items.body:
Using openshift-restclient-python with Python3 raises the following exception when de-serializing:

```python
File "/opt/app-root/lib/python3.6/site-packages/openshift/client/api_client.py", line 14, in _ApiClient__deserialize
--
  | data = {'Raw': b64encode(json.dumps(data))}
  | File "/opt/app-root/lib64/python3.6/base64.py", line 58, in b64encode
  | encoded = binascii.b2a_base64(s, newline=False)
  | TypeError: a bytes-like object is required, not 'str'

```

This looks like issue related bytes vs strings in Python2 and Python3.

items.title: Mismatch between OpenShift API spec and client APIs breaks SecurityContextConstraints

labels.name: triage/unresolved
labels.description: Indicates an issue that can not or will not be resolved.

items.body:
When you query the OpenShift API server, it claims that the SecurityContextConstraints resource is available on the `CoreV1Api` object.

```
>>> {r.kind for r in kubernetes.client.apis.core_v1_api.CoreV1Api().get_api_resources().resources}
{'Event', 'Scale', 'Service', 'ConfigMap', 'Eviction', 'SecurityContextConstraints', 'Namespace', 'Node', 'PodTemplate', 'Binding', 'ComponentStatus', 'PersistentVolume', 'LimitRange', 'PersistentVolumeClaim', 'ResourceQuota', 'Secret', 'Endpoints', 'ServiceAccount', 'ReplicationController', 'Pod'}
```

This is true for the OpenShift API server itself, since you can post a REST request against `/api/v1/securitycontextconstraints` and get something back.  It is *not* true, of course, for this client, because `CoreV1API` is a Kubernetes client class that doesn't know about OpenShift resources.  I've been discovering APIs by looking at the return values of `get_api_resources()` and other methods that ultimately depend on the API server but don't reflect what methods are available on the clients or where they're available.

Similarly, the [documentation](https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/tree/master/openshift) shows the security_context_constraints methods on the `CoreV1Api` object, but the [links are dead](https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/master/openshift/docs/CoreV1Api.md#create_security_context_constraints).

items.title: 4.0 breaks module parameter generation
items.body:
We rely on the `swagger_types` property in the models for generating module parameters, and for translating a config template into a Python object.

Consider the new swagger spec for V1DeploymentStrategy. Its swagger type has 2 properties: `type`, and `rolling_update`. If we see a `type` property, we know that there are multiple options for a type, and we expect each option be included in `swagger_types` in the form of `X_params`. Look at [V1DeploymentStrategy in version 3.4](https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/release-0.3.4/openshift/client/models/v1_deployment_strategy.py), and you will see 3 `X_params` options. We know those are the 3 choices for type, and we know the model for constructing the attributes of each param object.

Compare that to the new version. All the new version has is `rolling_update`, which doesn't line up at all with how our code works. Even the name `rolling_update` does not match with the actual value that API expects for a type. The API expects to see one of `rolling`, `recreate`, or `custom`, and it expects to receive a corresponding `X_params` value.

I have no idea how to fix this, without hard coding things to fill in the gaps left by the new swagger spec files.


In the 4.0 client, there's a bunch of additional validation code added to ensure that required fields can't be null/None.  Unfortunately, the Kubernetes API server will still return null/None values for some of these fields even though they're supposedly required.  I have a slightly more detailed explanation of a similar bug here:  https://github.com/kubernetes-client/python/issues/394 .  (It's closed but the issue is not fixed.)  I don't know if this is a bug in the OpenShift 3.6 API server (it's returning null for a required field) or the OpenAPI spec (the field shouldn't be required).

items.title: Dynamic API discovery Plan / POC
items.body:
@fabianvf  talked on IRC about this idea, and he's done a bit of hacking on it. The point of this ticket is for us to formalize a plan to actual produce a working POC. 

Questions:
- What does it mean for the swagger gen'd bits? Maybe all that goes away?
- How does it impact the client helpers, and downstream Ansible modules?
- Would we still need two separate client helpers?

items.title: Client changes types when parsing IntOrString
items.body:
When deserializing, the client parses values that swagger defines as `io.k8s.apimachinery.pkg.util.intstr.IntOrString` as only a string. This causes problems if you read an object, modify, then try to re-upload it in some cases.

Specifically, I hit this when reading a deployment, adding an attribute, and updating it (via ansible.kubernetes-modules). My strategy.rolling_update.max_surge in Kubernetes is integer `1`, but when the client deserializes, it coerces that value to a string. When that is then sent back to k8s, I get an error because if maxSurge is a string, it should have a `%` character at the end.

items.title: PreprocessingException causes a crash when running on OpenShift spec downloaded from a live server
items.body:
When the PreprocessingException is caught and this line is executed, https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/master/scripts/from_gen/preprocess_spec.py#L126, on Python 2.7 and 3.x it will raise an AttributeError because the `.message` attribute on BaseException was a deprecated feature only available in 2.6: https://sayspy.blogspot.ie/2007/05/baseexceptionmessage-is-now-deprecated.html .  I can submit a pull request to fix this, it's straightforward.  I don't know if the underlying error is something I should be worried about.  The form I'm seeing it in my tests is:

```
scripts.from_gen.preprocess_spec.PreprocessingException: Cannot find listNamespacedServiceAccount
```

I've had a hard time replicating this issue.  The systems I'm seeing this happen on is Python 3.5 on Ubuntu 16.04, but it's not reliable: one machine shows it, the other shows it only some of the time.  My best guess is that there's nondeterminism because of dict iteration order, that the process of reading the spec somehow involves the network, or both.

items.title: k8s_v1beta1_cluster_role_binding: role_ref_name is overwritten by object name
items.body:
Hi, I'm trying to create ClusterRoleBinding, using ansible-kubernetes-modules via following ansible specification:
```
- name: Grant permissions to GitLab Runner SA
    k8s_v1beta1_cluster_role_binding:
      state: present
      name: gitlab-runner2
      role_ref_api_group: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
      role_ref_kind: ClusterRole
      role_ref_name: cluster-admin
      subjects:
        - kind: ServiceAccount
          name: gitlab-runner
          namespace: "{{gitlab_ns}}"
```
As a result, I expect ServiceAccount `gitlab-runner` to be bound to ClusterRole `cluster-admin`
But, instead, I'm getting:
```
apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1beta1
kind: ClusterRoleBinding
metadata:
  creationTimestamp: 2017-11-05T12:02:14Z
  name: gitlab-runner2
  resourceVersion: "2589558"
  selfLink: /apis/rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1beta1/clusterrolebindings/gitlab-runner2
  uid: 29a5405b-c221-11e7-acf9-0ea794e93120
roleRef:
  apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
  kind: ClusterRole
  name: gitlab-runner2
subjects:
- kind: ServiceAccount
  name: gitlab-runner
  namespace: default
```
I suspect this happens, because `role_ref_name` has alias `name`, and there is overwritten by top-level `name` field

Also, is I use resource_definition to specify ClusterRoleBinding like this:
```
  - name: Grant permissions to GitLab Runner SA
    k8s_v1beta1_cluster_role_binding:
      state: present
      name: gitlab-runner2
      resource_definition:
        apiVersion: rbac.authorization.k8s.io/v1beta1
        kind: ClusterRoleBinding
        metadata:
          name: gitlab-runner2
        roleRef:
          apiGroup: rbac.authorization.k8s.io
          kind: ClusterRole
          name: cluster-admin
        subjects:
        - kind: ServiceAccount
          name: gitlab-runner
          namespace: default
```
I'm getting the following error:
```
TASK [cbr : Grant permissions to GitLab Runner SA] ****************************************************
Sunday 05 November 2017  15:12:33 +0300 (0:00:03.580)       0:00:03.637 ******* 
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "msg": "Error parsing resource definition. Encountered roleRef_api_group, which does not map to a module parameter. If this looks like a problem with the module, please open an issue at github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/issues"}

```

items.title: Need to filter log information in ansible helper
items.body:
The ansible helper code: https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/master/openshift/helper/ansible.py creates its own log objects and then proceeds to pass data that came into the AnsibleModule into this object.  This can be dangerous as some of the data could be sensitive information that should not be logged (example: passwords and other credentials).

The module author can specify things that should not be logged by marking an AnsibleModule parameter as no_log.  The helper function that logs how the module was invoked seems to use that for stripping the sensitive information from the log: https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/master/openshift/helper/ansible.py#L175.  However, it does not use the information to strip that information anywhere else that logging is called.  (For instance, if an http request is constructed with the sensitive information and then the request body is logged).

The end user may also specify that a task should not be logged via no_log: True in an ansible playbook.  This setting is not used at all in the openshift/helper/ansible.py code.

In Ansible's code base we're currently carrying two module_utils files that make use of this library but no modules using it.  We're thinking of several ways to mitigate the problem in the module_utils files (for instance, removing the debug parameter so users can't turn on the logging and/or switching the module_utils to use AnsibleModule.log() which takes these issues into account).  However, we cannot touch the issues in this code, nor prevent a module from switching debugging back on.  I'm opening this bug so that you can take steps, if you wish, to mitigate this in your own code (ideally, I think, by filtering all values that are sent to be logged similar to what AnsibleModule does, or using AnsibleModule's logging instead of creating your own logger.)

```
- name: "Define OpenShift Git Secret"
```

items.title: Module generation broken for openshift 3.6+
items.body: The naming schemes for kubernetes and openshift resources in the swagger spec now have the full package name, which makes the generated module names really long, and also breaks compatibility with the kubernetes client (which has changed it's whole generation method, it now has a single repo that runs a container that generates the modules). This blocks #85

items.title: Patch/replace route failing with exception
Allow to create "CustomResourceDefinition"
items.body: Currently, only ```ThirdPartyResource``` are supported, which is deprecated in kubernetes 1.7

items.title: Fail to translate camel case to snake case correctly
Default kube config not being picked up
items.body:
In 0.0.1 if auth options are set, specifying how to connect to kubernetes, the default config `~/.kube/config` (or the one specified in `KUBECONFIG`) was picked up and used.

The commit 13d5d86ca89035b9f596032e7a34f3cc33bf8f18 broke this. The only way to use a config file now is to explicitly specify one in `kubeconfig`.

---

I guess the proper way to handle this in [KubernetesObjectHelper.client_from_config](https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/master/openshift/helper/kubernetes.py#L18) is:

- If `config_file` is not set, and a default config file does not exist, then `return ApiClient(config=ConfigurationObject())`

This is how [load_kube_config](https://github.com/kubernetes-client/python-base/blob/824c03c7eee71dd5ac52fada8d7d36aecf81a781/config/kube_config.py#L333) determines which file to use:

``` python
KUBE_CONFIG_DEFAULT_LOCATION = os.environ.get('KUBECONFIG', '~/.kube/config')

if config_file is None:
  config_file = os.path.expanduser(KUBE_CONFIG_DEFAULT_LOCATION)
```

items.title: Consider making src come from templates
items.body:
Currently, it's possible to specify [`src`](https://github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/blob/master/openshift/helper/ansible.py#L135-L141) which allows loading a definition from a file. This gets loaded just as a [plain file](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/module_utils/k8s_common.py#L250-L261).

I think it would be better if this acted more like how some of the Ansible network modules work where `src` gets treated as a template. I'm guessing that the way people will use these Openshift/Kubernetes modules will be very similar to how people use the network modules. For example [vyos_config](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/network/vyos/vyos_config.py) and [asa_config](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/modules/network/asa/asa_config.py).

The template handling for these network modules all happens through Ansible's Action Plugins. A few examples can be found [here](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/plugins/action/net_config.py) and [here](https://github.com/ansible/ansible/blob/devel/lib/ansible/plugins/action/vyos_config.py).

Here are a few [links](https://www.ansible.com/blog/how-to-extend-ansible-through-plugins) to [documentation](http://ndemengel.github.io/2015/01/20/ansible-modules-and-action-plugins/) about Ansbile's Action Plugins.

This would take some changes to the upstream `k8s_common.py` module in Ansible but judging by how the network action plugins are setup, it looks like there should be an action generated for each module here possibly deriving all from a single class as is done with `net_config`. I'm just speculating around the best approach here.

items.title: BuildConfig (openshift_v1_build_config) module issues
items.body:
When using the `openshift_v1_build_config` in fusor/apb-base there are multiple issues.

Task
```
- name: Create BuildConfig                                                                                                                                                                                                                            
  openshift_v1_build_config:
    name: "{{ jenkins_service_name }}"
    namespace: "{{ namespace }}"
    spec_output_to_kind: "ImageStreamTag"
    spec_output_to_name: "jenkins:latest"
    spec_source_context_dir: "{{ source_context_dir }}"
    spec_source_git_uri: "{{ source_git_uri }}"
    spec_source_git_ref: "{{ source_git_ref }}"
    spec_source_type: "Git"
    spec_strategy_source_strategy__from_kind: "ImageStreamTag"
    spec_strategy_source_strategy__from_name: "jenkins:2"
    spec_strategy_source_strategy__from_namespace: "openshift"
    spec_triggers:
      - type: ConfigChange
      - type: ImageChange
    state: "{{ state }}"
    debug: True
  when: source_git_uri is defined and
        source_git_ref is defined and
        source_context_dir is defined
  ignore_errors: True
```
Result:
Incorrect JSON for BuildConfig see:
https://gist.github.com/jcpowermac/e24365ef4837cdc89bd004424bbbf07a
look for `_from`

Tasks
```
- name: Template - Create BuildConfig
  template:
    src: buildconfig.yaml.j2
    dest: /tmp/buildconfig.yaml
  register: buildconfig
  when: source_git_uri is defined and
        source_git_ref is defined and
        source_context_dir is defined

- name: Create BuildConfig
  openshift_v1_build_config:
    name: "{{ jenkins_service_name }}"
    namespace: "{{ namespace }}"
    debug: True
    src: "{{ buildconfig.dest | default(buildconfig.path) }}"
    state: "{{ state }}"
  when: source_git_uri is defined and
        source_git_ref is defined and
        source_context_dir is defined
```

Results:
```
TASK [provision-jenkins-apb : Create BuildConfig] ****************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************************
fatal: [localhost]: FAILED! => {"changed": false, "failed": true, "msg": "Error parsing resource definition. Encountered spec_strategy_source_strategy_from_kind, which does not map to a module parameter. If this looks like a problem with the module, please open an issue at github.com/openshift/openshift-restclient-python/issues"}
```
